verses.text: Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars for me here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
verses.comment: Maintains the imperative tone; direct translation of Balaam's request.

verses.text: Balak did just as Balaam said, and Balak and Balaam offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.comment: Clarifies that both participated in the sacrifices. The Hebrew grammar allows this interpretation.

verses.text: Balaam said to Balak, “Stand by your burnt offering, and I will go. Maybe the LORD will come to meet me, and whatever he shows me, I will tell you.” So he went to a bare hill.
verses.comment: ‘Bare hill’ translates 'barren height'; the term is accurate for the Hebrew word.

verses.text: God met Balaam, and Balaam said to him, “I have prepared seven altars, and I have offered a bull and a ram on each altar.”
verses.comment: Keeps Balaam’s report precise and matches Hebrew structure.

verses.text: The LORD put a word in Balaam’s mouth and said, “Go back to Balak, and this is what you shall say.”
verses.comment: “Put a word in Balaam’s mouth” closely follows Hebrew idiom; direct translation.

verses.text: So he went back to him, and Balak was standing by his burnt offering with all the chiefs of Moab.
verses.comment: Chiefs of Moab matches standard translation for ‘princes’; maintains clarity.

verses.text: Balaam took up his oracle and said: “Balak the king of Moab brought me from Aram, from the eastern mountains: ‘Come, curse Jacob for me, and come, denounce Israel!’”
verses.comment: ‘Oracle’ preserves Hebrew ‘mashal’; direct citation of Balak’s intent.

verses.text: “How can I curse whom God has not cursed? And how can I denounce whom the LORD has not denounced?”
verses.comment: The rhetorical question matches the poetic structure of the original.

verses.text: For from the top of the rocks I see him, and from the hills I observe him. Behold, a people dwelling alone, and not counted among the nations.
verses.comment: ‘Dwelling alone’ same as Hebrew; poetic metaphor kept intact.

verses.text: Who can count the dust of Jacob or number a fourth of Israel? Let me die the death of the upright, and let my end be like his!
verses.comment: ‘Dust of Jacob’ alludes to God’s promise to Abraham; footnotes not included but cross-references are present.

verses.text: Balak said to Balaam, “What have you done to me? I brought you to curse my enemies, and look, you have blessed them altogether!”
verses.comment: Emphasizes the reversal using ‘look’ for Hebrew ‘hineh’.

verses.text: Balaam replied, “Should I not speak what the LORD puts in my mouth?”
verses.comment: Follows the Hebrew form; rhetorical question implied.

verses.text: Balak said to him, “Please come with me to another place where you can see only part of them. You will not see all of them; from there, curse them for me.”
verses.comment: ‘Only part of them’ interprets Hebrew 'the end of them.'

verses.text: So he took him to the field of Zophim, on the top of Pisgah, and built seven altars and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.comment: Location and custom ritual repeated.

verses.text: Balaam said to Balak, “Stand here by your burnt offering while I meet with the LORD over there.”
verses.comment: “Meet with the LORD” translates Hebrew 'qara' for ‘to encounter.’

verses.text: The LORD met Balaam and put a word in his mouth, saying, “Go back to Balak, and speak this.”
verses.comment: Repeats earlier pattern; verbal structure follows Hebrew.

verses.text: He came to him, and Balak was standing by his burnt offering with the chiefs of Moab. Balak said to him, “What did the LORD say?”
verses.comment: Maintains setting and dialogue order.

verses.text: Balaam took up his oracle and said: “Rise, Balak, and listen! Hear me, son of Zippor!
verses.comment: ‘Oracle’ retains Hebrew ‘mashal;’ call to attention preserved.

verses.text: God is not a man, that he should lie, nor a son of man, that he should change his mind. Has he said, and will he not do it? Or has he spoken, and will he not fulfill it?
verses.comment: ‘Son of man’ preserved as idiom; logic of Hebrew parallelism rendered in clear English.

verses.text: Behold, I received a command to bless; he has blessed, and I cannot reverse it.
verses.comment: ‘Command to bless’ mirrors Hebrew ‘bless, and I cannot revoke.’

verses.text: He has not looked at wrongdoing in Jacob or seen trouble in Israel. The LORD their God is with them, and the shout of a king is among them.
verses.comment: ‘Shout of a king’ literal translation; some versions interpret as ‘triumphal shout.’

verses.text: God brought them out of Egypt; he has strength like a wild ox.
verses.comment: ‘Wild ox’ translates Hebrew ‘reem’; possible meaning: an extinct large wild bovine.

verses.text: For there is no sorcery against Jacob, nor divination against Israel. At this time it will be said of Jacob and Israel, ‘See what God has done!’
verses.comment: ‘Sorcery/divination’ maintains two separate Hebrew terms; idiomatic meaning preserved.

verses.text: Behold, a people rises like a lioness and lifts itself up like a lion. It does not lie down until it devours the prey and drinks the blood of the slain.
verses.comment: ‘Lioness’ and ‘lion’ are literal Hebrew terms; imagery retained for strength and courage.

verses.text: Balak said to Balaam, “Neither curse them at all nor bless them at all!”
verses.comment: Double negative expresses frustration; matches Hebrew repetition.

verses.text: Balaam replied to Balak, “Did I not tell you, ‘Whatever the LORD says, I must do’?”
verses.comment: Response echoes Balaam’s previous statements; fidelity to dialogue maintained.

verses.text: Balak said to Balaam, “Come, I will take you to another place. Perhaps it will please God, and you may curse them for me from there.”
verses.comment: ‘Perhaps it will please God’ retains the sense of uncertainty expressed in Hebrew.

verses.text: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, which overlooks the desert.
verses.comment: ‘Desert’ (Hebrew ‘wasteland’/‘Jeshimon’); geographical note remains.

verses.text: Balaam said, “Build seven altars for me here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
verses.comment: Direct repetition of ritual request as in v.1.

verses.text: Balak did as Balaam had said and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.comment: Completes the chapter’s cycle; summarizes the sacrificial action.
